Technical Assistance 
 
 
 
TAR: BHU 38410 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance to the 
Kingdom of Bhutan for the  
Capacity Building to Implement 
Environmental Assessment 
Procedures 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
August 2005

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 1 August 2005) 
 
Currency Unit –  ngultrum (Nu) 
Nu1.00 =  $0.0230 
$1.00 =  Nu43.55 
 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CA  –  competent authority 
EA  –  environmental assessment 
EAA  –  Environmental Assessment Act 
EC  –  environmental clearance 
FYP  –  Five-Year Plan 
NEC  –  National Environment Commission 
NECS  –  National Environment Commission Secretariat 
TA  –  technical assistance 
TOT  –  training of trainers 
     
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  Targeted intervention 
Sector  –  Agriculture and natural resources 
Subsector  –  Environment and biodiversity 
Themes  –  Governance, environmental sustainability 
Subthemes  –  Public governance, environmental policy and legislation  
 
 
 
NOTES 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This report was prepared by S. Ranawana.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   The Government of Bhutan requested the assistance of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for capacity building to implement its environmental assessment procedures, during the 
Country Strategy and Program Update Mission in 2004. ADB considered the request favorably 
(i) in view of the need to continue past capacity-building activities in the environment sector to a 
logical  conclusion,  and  (ii)  in  keeping  with  the  strategy  of  building  institutional  capacity  to 
facilitate ADB operations in the other key sectors. Technical assistance (TA)—Capacity Building 
to Implement Environmental Assessment Procedures—was therefore programmed for 2005.1 
The  scope,  implementing  arrangements,  cost  and  financing  arrangements,  and  terms  of 
reference of the TA were initially discussed with the Government in March 20042 and finalized at 
a Fact-Finding Mission in May 2005. The impact, outcomes, expected outputs, activities, and 
inputs are summarized in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bhutan has experienced a period of steady and significant economic growth (averaging 
7% per annum) since the 1970s. Economic growth coupled with improvements in basic social 
services has resulted in remarkable progress: per capita gross domestic product increased from 
$51 in 1961 to $830 in 2004, infant mortality was halved, enrollment in primary education 
increased fivefold, and life expectancy doubled during that period. This growth trend is likely to 
continue in the near to medium term. ADB’s Country Strategy Program (2006–2010)3 projects 
7–9% annual growth rates over the remaining period of the Ninth Five–Year Plan (2002–2007) 
(9FYP) and 10–12% growth rates during the first half of the 10FYP.  
 
3.  Much  of  the  public  investment  program  in  Bhutan  is  financed  by  its  development 
partners.  Therefore,  external  assistance  to  Bhutan  is  also  likely  to  increase  in  the  future, 
corresponding with the country’s growth projections. ADB alone is expected to increase lending 
to Bhutan by over threefold in the coming years (from a historical average of $7–$10 million per 
annum to about $32 million per annum in 2006–2010. The 9FYP represented a 75% increase in 
expenditure over the 8FYP, and a similar increment is likely with the 10FYP.  
 
4.  In 1990, the Government adopted the Paro Resolution, pledging to balance economic 
development  with  environmental  protection  and  sustainable  use  of  natural  resources.  This 
principle  of  “environmentally  sustainable  development”  is  embodied  in  the  national 
environmental  strategy  titled,  The  Middle  Path  (1998)  and  also  in  Bhutan’s  long-term 
development plan titled, Bhutan 2020: A Vision for Peace, Prosperity and Happiness (1999). 
The  latter  document  stresses  the  need  to  institutionalize  the  capacity  to  undertake 
environmental  impact  assessments  as  a  means  of  achieving  environmentally  sustainable 
development. Accordingly, an Act to legitimize environmental assessment (EA) procedures (the 
Environmental Assessment Act [EAA]) was  passed in 2000 and corresponding regulations 
(Regulations  for  Environmental  Clearance  of  Projects  and  Regulations  for  Strategic 
Environmental Assessment) were adopted in 2002. The EAA and Regulations generally reflect 
the core principles of standard EA practices.   
 
                                                 
1 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet edition) on 28 January 2005. 
2 During the final tripartite meeting of TA4120-BHU (ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for 
Strengthening Environment Sector Capacity. Manila.). 
3 Draft circulated for interdepartmental review on 2 June 2005.

2   
5.  On the institutional front, the National Environment Commission (NEC) was established 
in 1992. This high-level policy-making and regulatory body is chaired by the planning minister 
and comprises senior officers from different sectors. The deputy minister of environment serves 
as the secretary of NEC and heads the NEC Secretariat (NECS). NECS is empowered under 
the  EAA  as  the  principal  agency  responsible  for  enforcing  the  provisions  of  the  Act  and 
Regulations. To date, most requests for environmental clearance of projects are referred to 
NECS. However, NECS will soon be unable to cope with the workload involved with processing 
an increasing volume of such requests and the parallel responsibility of monitoring ongoing 
projects.  
 
6.  The  EAA  enables  NEC  to  authorize  Competent  Authorities  (CAs)4  to  issue 
environmental clearance for projects in the respective sectors, before consent to develop is 
awarded to the same. A provision in the EAA for CAs to assume the functions of NECS will 
ease a potential bottleneck in the project approval process. This arrangement of subsidiarity is 
consistent with the constitution of Bhutan, which is currently being drafted. The Government has 
therefore awarded high priority to decentralizing responsibility for EA procedures. NECS retains 
the authority to issue environmental clearance of projects for which the respective CA is the 
applicant. NECS also continues to assume primary responsibility for monitoring compliance with 
the  environmental  clearance  process  and  is  required  to  report  annually  to  NEC  on  the 
performance. 
 
7.  Before  decentralizing  responsibilities  for  implementing  the  environmental  clearance 
guidelines, relevant staff from these agencies must be trained in EA techniques and procedures. 
In addition, high-level policy makers, project proponents, practitioners of EA and contractors of 
large civil works projects also need varying degrees of exposure and training in the substantive 
and procedural aspects of EAs. The subject TA aims to provide the required training and 
exposure programs. 
 
8.  ADB has supported Bhutan with capacity building in the environment sector over a 
period of time. A TA to formulate sectoral EA guidelines was approved in 1996.5 The TA was 
instrumental in developing six key sectors guidelines that were adopted in 1999. However, even 
as these guidelines were being adopted, NEC recognized the need for a legal basis to enforce 
environmental clearance procedures. Therefore, NEC embarked on the task of drafting the EAA 
and regulations, benefiting largely from the experience gained from implementing environmental 
clearance procedures over the years. The EAA and regulations rendered the sectoral guidelines 
somewhat dated; hence, NEC sought ADB assistance to revise them and develop additional 
guidelines for some new sectors. ADB conceded and approved a TA in 2003.6 The revised 
guidelines are now being adopted by sector agencies, several of which are designated CA. 
Overall, ADB’s involvement in strengthening Bhutan’s capacity to undertake EAs has been seen 
as a valuable contribution. The TAs have delivered effective outcomes with relatively small 
amounts of resources. Although ADB was not directly involved in their drafting, the EAA and 
regulations have benefited from earlier experience gained from the first TA.  
 
                                                 
4  CAs are agencies authorized to issue development consent for a project under Article 6.4 of the Environmental 
Assessment Act, 2000. 
5  ADB. 1996. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Strengthening Environmental Impact Assessment 
Capabilities and Preparation of Environmental Guidelines. Manila. 
6  ADB. 2003. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Strengthening Environmental Sector Capacity 
Project. Manila.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  In  terms  of  overall  impact,  the  TA  will  contribute  to  Bhutan’s  achievement  of  the 
Millennium Development Goals in line with the Paro Declaration (1990) on balancing economic 
development  with  environmental  protection.  The  specific  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be 
enhancement of the effectiveness and efficiency in implementing EA procedures in Bhutan. This 
will be achieved by (i) improving the capacity of government officials at all levels to implement 
the environmental clearance procedures, (ii) improving the technical capacity of EA practitioners 
and proponents of development projects in the country, and (iii) developing a core group of 
trainers to conduct in-country training in environmental assessment. The impact, outcome, and 
outputs are summarized in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. In phase 1, a program for training of trainers 
in EA procedures will be designed and implemented. A team of trainers will be selected from 
among staff of NECS, CAs, appropriate training institute(s) and selected private institutions 
(e.g., the industry sector and the mining industry). The team will learn about EA procedures of 
other  countries  in  the  region  through  an  exposure  program  comprising  a  study  tour  and 
literature review. Thereafter, the team will prepare a series of training modules to target a range 
of end users.  
 
11.  Training modules will target different stakeholder groups including (i) politicians, high-
level public officials, law enforcement officials, and prosecutors who need to be aware of the 
general provisions of the EAA and regulations; (ii) regulators (i.e., staff of CAs, Dzongkhag 
[district]  environmental  committees)  who  are  responsible  for  reviewing  and  approving 
environmental clearance documents; (iii) potential practitioners and project proponents who will 
undertake EAs in the course of designing and implementing a development project; and (iv) civil 
works contractors who undertake infrastructure projects. 
 
12.  A training institute will be identified during phase 1 to host the training sessions that will 
be conducted during the TA. The institute will be selected from among those approved by the 
Government for delivery of external training programs.7 Criteria for selecting the institute will 
include (i) relevance of its mandate to the proposed training programs in EA procedures, (ii) 
ability to reach potential trainees over a wide geographic area, (iii) willingness to incorporate the 
training modules into its core teaching curricula with the intention of continuing similar training 
programs beyond the TA period, and (iv) flexibility to work with resource persons from outside 
the institute, such as the trainers developed under the TA. 
 
13.  Phase 2 will be devoted to delivery of a series of training programs adopting the training 
modules developed during phase 1. Five training programs are scheduled, targeting a total of 
325 participants. The programs will last from 5 to 8 days, except for the high-level programs 
targeting politicians, judges, and senior bureaucrats. The latter will be limited to a couple of 1-
day programs. The training programs are staggered over a period of 10 months to provide 
sufficient flexibility to the trainers and the NECS staff who will serve as resource persons in 
                                                 
7  Government authorized institutes are (i) Royal Institute of Management, (ii) Natural Resources Training Institute, 
and (iii) Royal Bhutan Institute of Technology in Phuensholing.

4   
addition to their regular official duties. The modules will also be modified and improved with the 
experience gained with each training session.  
 
14.  In addition to the procedural aspects of complying with the EAA, the training modules will 
cover the conceptual foundations, underlying theories, and substantive techniques involved in 
EA. The degree of coverage will vary by target audience and duration of the course.  At the end 
of the TA, NECS will prepare a report evaluating the training programs. More broadly, the report 
will  cover  lessons  learned  from  enforcing  the  EAA  and  indicate  areas  needing  further 
development or refinement. This report will be discussed at the final meeting between the 
Government and ADB. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $236,000 equivalent, comprising $65,200 in 
foreign currency and $170,800 equivalent in local currency. The Government has requested 
ADB to finance the total foreign currency cost and $134,800 equivalent of the local currency 
cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The Government 
will finance the balance of the local currency cost equivalent of $36,000 through the provision of 
in-kind contributions. Appendix 2 contains a detailed breakdown of the cost estimates and the 
financing plan. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  NECS will serve as both Implementing and Executing Agency of the TA. A TA project 
coordinator and an alternate will be appointed by NECS before the TA starts. The project 
coordinator will be responsible for overall administration and coordination of TA activities. NECS 
will undertake the following key responsibilities (i) facilitate the selection of trainers, (ii) provide 
guidance during development of the training modules, (iii) assist in identifying an appropriate 
training institute, and (iv) identify suitable candidates to receive training. 
 
17.  The Government agrees to support the TA by (i) establishing a project management 
team at NECS comprising a coordinator, an alternate coordinator, and other specialists from 
within and outside NECS who will be co-opted on a need basis; (ii) providing office space on 
NECS premises, communications, and other office facilities for the consultants who will be 
engaged under the TA; (iii) providing resource persons and facilities for workshops and training 
sessions; and (iv) providing administrative support for routine TA administration activities.  
 
18.  The TA will provide 1.5 person-months of international and 8 person-months of domestic 
consulting  service  inputs.  The  international  consultant  will  be  a  training  specialist  with 
experience in EA training. The consultant will be responsible for the outcomes related to (i) 
preparing and conducting the study tour, (ii) training of trainers, and (iii) preparing the training 
modules. The domestic consultant will be an environmental specialist with experience in a wide 
range of sectors. This consultant will be responsible for effective delivery of the outcomes 
related to (i) carrying out the training programs, (ii) modifying the training modules based on 
experience gained from conducting training programs, and (iii) establishing links with a suitable 
training institute. The consultants will work closely with NECS to ensure smooth implementation 
of the overall TA. Detailed terms of reference of the consultants are in Appendix 3. ADB will 
engage the consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the selection and engagement of domestic consultants.

5
19.  The TA will be implemented in two phases, comprising a period of 15 months in total. 
Phase 1 will cover 4 months commencing in September 2005, and phase 2 in 11 months. The 
TA is expected to be completed by November 2006. Detailed implementation schedule is in 
Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Bhutan  for  Capacity  Building  to  Implement  Environmental  Assessment 
Procedures, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Environmental Assessment Training Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months) 
1.  The specialist will perform the following tasks in close collaboration with the National 
Environment Commission Secretariat (NECS) and with the domestic environmental specialist. 
(i)  Assist  in  identifying  countries  with  relevant  environmental  assessment  (EA) 
procedures that could be included in the exposure tour under the training of 
trainers (TOT) program; 
(ii)  Obtain  literature  on  the  EA  procedures  and  techniques  of  these  countries 
(including information on legislation, institutional arrangements for EA, training 
procedures, and material); 
(iii)  Review  the  EA  procedures  of  Bhutan—including  the  National  Environmental 
Strategy (1998), Environmental Assessment Act (2000) and Regulations (2002), 
Environmental  Clearance  Guidelines  for  Sectors  (2004)—and  determine  the 
most suitable contents for dissemination to different target groups; 
(iv)  Advise NECS on criteria for selecting candidates for the TOT program; 
(v)  Conduct an orientation for selected candidates for the TOT program before the 
overseas exposure tour; 
(vi)  Develop best-practice guidelines on  
(a)  format and content of training aids, 
(b)  training delivery techniques, and 
(c)  evaluation of training programs 
(vii)  Advise and assist the trainers in preparing training modules for different target 
groups; 
(viii)  Demonstrate  and  train  trainers  in  delivery  techniques  by  conducting  mock 
sessions and by participating in at least one formal training program; 
(ix)  Prepare a report describing the TOT program, including recommendations for 
improvement if any; and 
(x)  Perform other tasks as required by NECS and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB). 
  
B.  Environmental Specialist (domestic, 8 person-months) 
2.  The specialist will perform the following tasks in close collaboration with NECS and with 
the international EA training specialist. 
(i)  Assist in and continue the activities initiated by the international EA training 
specialist; 
(ii)  Be responsible for overall coordination of the TOT program, including organizing 
and carrying out the overseas exposure tour;

Appendix 3  9 
(iii)  Prepare  a  report  on  the  overseas  exposure  program  listing  useful  contacts, 
sources of information on EA, recommendations for establishing links between 
Bhutan and the countries visited, and other recommendations for improving the 
EA procedure in Bhutan; 
(iv)  Assist NECS in identifying and establishing links with a training institute that 
would serve as the host for some/all the training programs; 
(v)  Take lead responsibility for coordinating and facilitating the preparation of training 
modules;  
(vi)  Be responsible for managing all operational funds of the technical assistance 
(TA) and disburse them according to ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement, for the 
following  purposes  (a)  consultations,  workshops,  and  training  programs;  
conducting  the  overseas  exposure  program;  (c)  procuring  stationary  and 
consumables  for  implementing  the  TA;  (d)  paying  government-established 
allowances  to  local  government  staff  attending  training  programs;  (e)  hiring  
vehicles for transportation during training programs; and (f) printing, translating 
and binding documents and other training material. It is understood that NECS 
will provide administrative support in obtaining quotations, procuring material, 
and executing payments; 
(vii)  Assist  NECS  in  preparing  the  final  report  evaluating  the  training  programs 
conducted  under  the  TA,  and  more  broadly  assessing  the  EA  process  by 
identifying strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of the process; and 
(viii)  Perform any other tasks as required by NECS and ADB.
